awd_titl_txt: University of Alaska Fairbanks/Sikuliaq Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment - 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the Academic Research Fleet (ARF) fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. UAF requests funds to purchase and install Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment that would enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2021, Sikuliaq completed 233 days 181 (78%) of which were for NSF. In 2022, the vessel is scheduled to sail 275 days with 217 (79%) days of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment.

1)	Electromechanical hybrid winch cable	$18,760
2)	Winding and tension carts for spooling	$79,411
3)	Water weight bags for load testing	$32,185
							$130,356

Broader Impacts				
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
We have strategically acquired new equipment to enhance the capabilities of R/V Sikuliaq to support science missions.

- Electromechanical hybrid cable for underwire winch

Southbay manufactured the 800-meter length of custom cable and delivered it in the fall of 2022. It was spooled onto Sikuliaq's underwire winch, located on the starboard crane boom, in early 2023. It has been regularly used to support lightweight operations off the side such as vertical ring nets, oblique bongo nets, iron fish tows, glider deployment and recoveries, and so on. We utilize the electrical conductors in the cable for attaching a small CTD, which is helpful for net tows to know the exact depth throughout the tow.

- Winding and tension carts for spooling

Due to supply chain issues, ReelPower delivered the spooling carts in spring of 2023. They have been used aboard Sikuliaq and shoreside at Seward Marine Center for supporting mooring cruises and small-scale wire spooling operations. They are simple to use, and built to withstand the harsh environment at sea. 

- Water weight bags for load testing

The water bags were delivered in the fall of 2022. They were used on a number of occassions in the winter of 2023 to load test Sikuliaq's two cargo cranes, small boat davits, CTD launch and recovery system, and calibrate the load cells for the science winches. In the winter of 2024, the water bags were used to load test Sikuliaq's A-frame. When not needed by UAF, the water bags are stored at UW so they may be used for load testing on Thompson and Rachel Carson.

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2024
Modified by: Ethan H Roth
